Title.evidence: A Multicentre Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Olanexidine and Chlorhexidine-Alcohol for Surgical-Site Antisepsis

Trial_Design.evidence: This multicentre, randomised, open-label, blinded-endpoint controlled trial was conducted in five Japanese hospitals.

Participants.evidence: Participants were adults undergoing elective clean-contaminated gastrointestinal and hepatobiliary-pancreatic surgeries.

Intervention.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of aqueous olanexidine compared with chlorhexidine-alcohol in preventing SSIs.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of aqueous olanexidine compared with chlorhexidine-alcohol in preventing SSIs.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the 30-day SSI rate.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a web-based system with block randomisation, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Between January 2023 and November 2023, 700 patients were randomised: 350 to the olanexidine group and 350 to the chlorhexidine-alcohol group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: In the full analysis set, 347 patients in the olanexidine group and 345 in the chlorhexidine-alcohol group were analysed.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The 30-day SSI rate was 12.3% in the olanexidine group and 13.6% in the chlorhexidine-alcohol group (adjusted risk ratio 0.911, 95% CI 0.625 to 1.327; P = 0.626).

Harms.evidence: Adverse effects were reported in 0.6% of the olanexidine group and 0.9% of the chlorhexidine-alcohol group.

Funding.evidence: The study was independently conducted by Keio University.
